chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: Back in 1895, the U.S. Open Golf Championship presented the champion with a prize of $150. For 2016 this prize is significantly higher in face value. We need to calculate at which rate has the prize increased over the years and the value of it in the year 2040 if this keeps increasing at the same rate.

We know the following data:

U.S. Open Golf Championship 
-
|Year|Prize|
|--|--|
2016 |$1,800,000
1895 |$150

To know the rate to which the prize has increased during the years, we need to use the formula of Future Value (FV) and rearrange it to obtain the rate.

$$ \begin{aligned}
FV &= PV\cdot(1+r)^{t} \\
\\
r & = \sqrt[t]{\frac{FV}{PV}}-1
\end{aligned}$$

*Where:*
- PV is the present value
- r is the applied rate
- t is the periods of time the rate is applied

Now we can apply the formula to obtain the rate at which the prize has increased during this timeframe. 

$$ \begin{aligned}
r & = \sqrt[121]{\frac{\$1,800,000}{\$150}}-1\\
\\
& = \boxed{8.07\%}
\end{aligned}$$

The prize has increased **8.07%** on average during the last 121 years.
